docs.snippet: Ten days after the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens was toppled, members of the Chilean delegation here seem intent on trying to restore the semblance of a normal routine.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ten days after the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens was toppled, members of the Chilean delegation here seem intent on trying to restore the semblance of a normal routine.
docs.abstract: impact on Chilean deleation of overthrow of Pres Allende and installment of mil junta in Chile discussed; delegates trying to restore semblance of normal routine; Amb R Bazan is now acting head of delegation; J Holger had temporary charge immediately following Allende overthrow

byline.original: By KATHLEEN TELTSCHSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Juan Domingo Per6n has now completed an astonishing political comeback by winning the Presidency of Argentina with more than 60 per cent of the vote in a free election. Mr. Peron overcame major handicaps: eighteen years of exile, his age (he will be...
docs.lead_paragraph: Juan Domingo Per6n has now completed an astonishing political comeback by winning the Presidency of Argentina with more than 60 per cent of the vote in a free election. Mr. Peron overcame major handicaps: eighteen years of exile, his age (he will be 78 four days before taking office Oct. 12), and the insistence that his wife, Isabel, be nominated Vice President despite strong opposition from some left-wing supporters.
docs.abstract: ed says that J D Peron's decisive victory in Argentine pres election clearly places on him responsibility of pulling country out of pol and econ quagmire; notes this will not be easy in view of his age, ill health, lack of cohesion within his movement and unpopularity of his wife and Vice Pres, Isabel, among left-wing Peronists; says that revival of nationalism and statism that brought Argentina to edge of bankruptcy between '46 and 55 would lose him support of those who are welcoming him back only as alternative to floundering mil rule

docs.snippet: To the Editor: The "infinitesimal risk" of cancer caused by nuclear power plants claimed in his Sept. 14 letter by Dr. L. D. Hamilton of the Brookhaven National Laboratory (an institution funded by the Atomic Energy. Commission) is replete with...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The "infinitesimal risk" of cancer caused by nuclear power plants claimed in his Sept. 14 letter by Dr. L. D. Hamilton of the Brookhaven National Laboratory (an institution funded by the Atomic Energy. Commission) is replete with glaring flaws in logic.
docs.abstract: J M Hoenig lr questions whether Vice Pres Agnew's right to fair trial will be infringed upon because of excessive pretrial publicity if he is impeached and removed from office because of Md scandals

docs.snippet: Virtually alone, Harald Edel stam saved the Cuban Embassy from being stormed and provided protection to Chilean, Brazilian and other political refugees. He is a prime mover behind an international effort to win guarantees for security for opponents...
docs.lead_paragraph: Virtually alone, Harald Edel stam saved the Cuban Embassy from being stormed and provided protection to Chilean, Brazilian and other political refugees. He is a prime mover behind an international effort to win guarantees for security for opponents of Chile's new military rulers.
docs.abstract: article on efforts of Swedish Amb to Chile H Edelstam on behalf of Cubans and other nationals in Chile; notes that he is prime mover behind internatl effort to win guarantees for security of opponents of Chile's mil rulers; notes his criticism of UN and IRC for lack of effective action; records his efforts to prevent storming of Cuban Embassy in Santiago and to secure transport of embassy staff out of country; crowded conditions in certain Santiago embassies noted; Chilean decision to refuse safe passage out of country to pol dissidents and its determination to prosecute those foreign refugees who it thinks are enemies of Govt noted

headline.main: Swedish Ambassador Extends Shelter To Refugees of Chile's Political Storm; U.N. Is Criticized No Pact on Asylum

byline.original: By MARVINE HOWESpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: HONOLULU -- The moon controls tidal flows on this planet but no one has yet calculated what governs cyclical changes in world politics. Nevertheless, just as the past decade saw global gains in various leftwardtending movements around the earth, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU -- The moon controls tidal flows on this planet but no one has yet calculated what governs cyclical changes in world politics. Nevertheless, just as the past decade saw global gains in various leftwardtending movements around the earth, the present one sees an edging toward the right.
docs.abstract: C L Sulzberger article on evidence world pol trend in '70s is toward right; discusses situation in various areas and specific countries, saying most extreme and dangerous change has been in S Amer; says trend probably stems from Sino-Soviet rift, which divides Communist pol impetus, and realization that welfare state systems are costly to maintain in dem societies

headline.main: Edging Toward the Right; FOREIGN AFFAIRS

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: AMERICAN NATIONS AND WESTERN HEMISPHERE POSSESSIONS

headline.main: RUSSIAN IS WINNER OF CLIBURN CONTEST

docs.abstract: Zaire Pres Mobutu Sese Seko on Oct 4 announces in speech to UN General Assembly that his nation is breaking diplomatic relations with Israel; Zaire is 8th African country to break relations with Israel in last 20 mos

headline.main: SOUTH AFRICANS CHALLENGED IN U.N.; Black Nations Lead Effort to Reject Credentials
